content:
The other thread you're referring to was merely the user not understanding what was happening. There was no problem to solve there, it was working as expected, hence why no follow ups.

It isn't clear whether that's your case as well or not. Is it that Google keeps repeatedly asking you to authorise Thunderbird, even after you've completed the authorisation process? Or is it that you don't understand why it's doing so? Because if the latter, it could simply be that the OAuth token kept by Thunderbird to be able to connect to the server has expired and Google requires you to authorise Thunderbird again…
creator: DavidGG

content: There are other ways to create a new message, that's not the only way, but you may make the button appear by choosing View > Folders > Folder Pane Header in the menu bar.
creator: DavidGG

content:
That would depend on whether the accounts were set up as POP or as IMAP, i.e. whether your mail is being stored locally or on the server. Obviously anything on the server will be gone when the accounts are cancelled…

But you may avoid this problem entirely, regardless of the type of account, by creating custom folders under Local Folders, at the bottom of the list of accounts in the folder pane, to store and organise your mail locally on your computer there however you wish, independently of any account you may have. Mail stored there won't be affected by the accounts being cancelled or even by you removing the accounts from Thunderbird yourself.
creator: DavidGG

content:
Export your profile on the old computer. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/thunderbird-export

Import your profile on the new computer. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/thunderbird-import
creator: christ1

content:
Export/Import isn't very convenient for this. In addition to that requiring a special procedure if the size of the profile folder is greater than 2 GB, importing your profile on the new computer would require Thunderbird to be already running there to begin with, and then Thunderbird won't even let you import a profile without setting up a mail account first…

The following article describes a better way to do it:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer
creator: DavidGG

content: Well, for the record, before posting my previous reply I tried to run Thunderbird without setting up a mail account, and the Tools > Import command was disabled, hence what I said. But I tried again now (while checking something else), and this time the Import command was enabled, so contrary to what I said, it looks like it is (or should be) possible to import an existing profile (no greater than 2 GB) that way without having to set up a mail account first.
creator: DavidGG

content:
Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)

content: First, if you copy the profile from old to new, the addressbook and everything else will appear on new computer. Since you apparently didn't do that, my suggestion is to copy the abook.sqlite and history.sqlite from the profile on old computer and paste into the profile on new computer - while thunderbird is NOT running.
creator: davidsk

content:
Do you have any Message Filters? This sounds like you have a filter you created yourself that's not working as expected…

I just accidentally emptied that junk box. Is there any way of getting those emails back now?

What type of mail account is this (POP/IMAP)? If POP and the messages are still on the server, you may make Thunderbird download them again. If IMAP, then the messages have been deleted from both Thunderbird and the server, and there is no way to get them back unless you have a backup.

You may want to check the Bin/Trash, in case you just moved them there rather than permanently delete them. And you may use webmail to check whether the messages are still available on the server. In particular, if this is a Gmail account, you should check the All Mail folder in case the messages are still there.
creator: DavidGG

content:
What are your account Copies & Folders settings for Message Archives? You may need to choose Other, then select the iCloud Archive folder on the server you want Thunderbird to use for that.

Note that by default Thunderbird will try to use a folder called "Archives" (plural), whereas the one in iCloud may be called "Archive" (singular), which is why you may need to point Thunderbird to the right folder you want it to use for that.
creator: DavidGG

content:
In the menu bar, choose View > Folders > Folder Pane Header if not already ticked, to make that visible. Then, click on the '···' button to the right of the '+ New Message' button in that pane to display a list of options. One of the options available there near the bottom should be Hide Local Folders, which you have probably ticked, select it to untick it and make the Local Folders appear in the folder pane.

The following article shows the Folder Pane Header and explains the options available there:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/new-thunderbird-115-supernova#w_look-and-feel-improvements-new-message-button-get-messages-folder-pane-options-meatball-menu
creator: DavidGG

content:
Which is your email provider? Post a screenshot of your outgoing (SMTP) server settings, so we may verify they're correct.

Read the following article in the meantime to see possible causes of the problem:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/cannot-send-messages
creator: DavidGG

content:
Post a screenshot of your outgoing (SMTP) server settings, so we may verify they're correct.

Read the following article in the meantime to see possible causes of the problem:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/cannot-send-messages

In particular, if you're using a VPN, disable it and see whether that makes the problem go away. If it does, check whether your VPN has an option called split tunneling which would allow you to let Thunderbird bypass the VPN.
creator: DavidGG
